awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Acoustic Field-Assisted Stereolithography for Multi-Material Additive Nanomanufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The successful development of nanomachines is pivotal for the realization of future intelligent nanorobots, nanofactories, and nanomedicine. Through applications in nano and micro surgery, targeted drug delivery, and environmental pollutant removal, the impact of nanomachines on every aspect of daily lives as well as the global economy is expected to be significant. However, the manufacturing of nanomachines is challenging due to the difficulty in combining multiple materials or assembling multiple components into a three-dimensional structure to achieve the desired functionalities. Most currently reported nano and micromachines are limited to very simple designs with spherical or cylindrical geometries and thus limited functions, while requiring a large amount of labor, time, and cost for fabrication. This award investigates the scalable and efficient manufacturing of multi-material three-dimensional objects consisting of arbitrarily distributed nano-sized building-blocks. The project studies the advent of multi-functionality by nanoparticle localization through patterning and building 3D objects by solidifying particle-polymer suspensions layer-by-layer. Furthermore, this research advances knowledge of multi-material structure design and development, and paves the way for a new scientific paradigm for the design, fabrication, and application of multi-functional nanomachines. Course modules on additive nanomanufacturing are planned for education in engineering both at the two collaborative universities and at local middle and high schools. Special attention is given to encourage the participation of women, persons with disabilities, and traditionally underrepresented groups. 

Current manufacturing methods for nanomachines are limited by scalability, efficiency, and material and geometric diversity. To overcome these constraints, this project aims to establish a new additive nanomanufacturing strategy for fabricating 3D multi-material particle-polymer nanocomposites, and to test the hypothesis that the localized nanoparticle distribution can produce multi-functionalities. The research approach -- acoustic field-assisted stereolithography -- utilizes an acoustic field to pattern nanoparticles with macro-to-nano scale resolutions and build a 3D object by solidifying the particle-polymer suspensions layer-by-layer. This research integrates multiple physical phenomena with nanomanufacturing and involves various disciplines of science and engineering including modeling and simulation, process design and development, material and device characterization. This project contributes to advances in additive nanomanufacturing, nanotechnology, and innovations in nanomaterials and nanomachines.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
By combining various polymers and particles that serve mechanical, electrical, chemical, thermal, and/or optical functions with controlled distributions at nano- or micro-scale in a component, nano-/micro-machines with multiple functionalities can be fabricated. Top-down lithography and bottom-up assembly of nanoscale building blocks are the two most widely used methods for multi-material and multi-functional nano-/micro- manufacturing. Yet they are labor intensive, time consuming, and limited to simple geometries in many cases.  This project aims to establish a new multi-material and multi-scale additive manufacturing strategy by integrating acoustic field-assisted particle patterning into photopolymerization-based additive manufacturing processes and to fabricate three-dimensional (3D) and multi-material particle-polymer nanocomposite structures for a wide range of applications. 

Outcomes- Intellectual merit:

This project established the fundamental knowledge of particle-resin flow dynamics under different acoustic field settings, acoustic field-assisted particle patterning methods, acoustic streaming effects in two-photon polymerization process, particle-polymer composite materials, and particle-polymer multi-material properties.  In particular, mechanisms for integrating acoustic fields into projection stereolithography process and two-photon polymerization process were established.  Interactions between particles, liquid resin, and laser were understood.  Knowledge of the multimaterial nano-/micro- additive manufacturing machine design and process planning was also generated.  In addition, the project also demonstrated various test cases fabricated by the manufacturing knowledge and setup developed in this project. Examples include self-driven microfluidic devices, programmable adhesive films, objects with efficient heat dissipation, surfaces with enhanced fog harvesting properties and enhanced light trapping properties, and so on.  Together with these test case studies, this research project modeled and validated the effects of acoustic field settings and additive manufacturing process parameter settings on the printed particle-polymer composition patterns, nano-/micro-scale feature geometries and properties.

Outcomes- Broader Impacts:

This project solved challenges in the design of multimaterial nano-/micro-additive manufacturing processes and machines, for the production of objects with spatially-varying particle-polymer compositions and nano-/micro- features.  Moreover, this project made an impact on functional part and device design and production, which is very likely to make impacts on every aspect of our daily lives as well as the economy, through applications in fields including surface engineering, soft robotics, biomedical devices, and so on.  Research outcomes have been integrated into the PI's courses: “ME/IE 594 Advanced Topics in 3D Printing/ Additive Manufacturing”, “ME/IE 481 Additive Manufacturing Processes”, “IE596 Independent Study”, and “IE392 Undergraduate Research”.  Multiple graduate and undergraduate students were recruited to work on this project and being trained, including students from under-represented groups and low-income families.  Among them, two female PhD students graduated with dissertations developed or partially developed from this project and another female PhD student will graduate in 2023 with a dissertation majorly developed from this project.  More than ten journal papers were developed from this research and have been published.  Furthermore, the project results were disseminated widely to research communities through conferences and seminars and the general public through lab tours and news coverages.  


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Yayue Pan
por.por_txt_cntn:
By combining various polymers and particles that serve mechanical, electrical, chemical, thermal, and/or optical functions with controlled distributions at nano- or micro-scale in a component, nano-/micro-machines with multiple functionalities can be fabricated. Top-down lithography and bottom-up assembly of nanoscale building blocks are the two most widely used methods for multi-material and multi-functional nano-/micro- manufacturing. Yet they are labor intensive, time consuming, and limited to simple geometries in many cases.  This project aims to establish a new multi-material and multi-scale additive manufacturing strategy by integrating acoustic field-assisted particle patterning into photopolymerization-based additive manufacturing processes and to fabricate three-dimensional (3D) and multi-material particle-polymer nanocomposite structures for a wide range of applications. 

Outcomes- Intellectual merit:

This project established the fundamental knowledge of particle-resin flow dynamics under different acoustic field settings, acoustic field-assisted particle patterning methods, acoustic streaming effects in two-photon polymerization process, particle-polymer composite materials, and particle-polymer multi-material properties.  In particular, mechanisms for integrating acoustic fields into projection stereolithography process and two-photon polymerization process were established.  Interactions between particles, liquid resin, and laser were understood.  Knowledge of the multimaterial nano-/micro- additive manufacturing machine design and process planning was also generated.  In addition, the project also demonstrated various test cases fabricated by the manufacturing knowledge and setup developed in this project. Examples include self-driven microfluidic devices, programmable adhesive films, objects with efficient heat dissipation, surfaces with enhanced fog harvesting properties and enhanced light trapping properties, and so on.  Together with these test case studies, this research project modeled and validated the effects of acoustic field settings and additive manufacturing process parameter settings on the printed particle-polymer composition patterns, nano-/micro-scale feature geometries and properties.

Outcomes- Broader Impacts:

This project solved challenges in the design of multimaterial nano-/micro-additive manufacturing processes and machines, for the production of objects with spatially-varying particle-polymer compositions and nano-/micro- features.  Moreover, this project made an impact on functional part and device design and production, which is very likely to make impacts on every aspect of our daily lives as well as the economy, through applications in fields including surface engineering, soft robotics, biomedical devices, and so on.  Research outcomes have been integrated into the PI's courses: "ME/IE 594 Advanced Topics in 3D Printing/ Additive Manufacturing", "ME/IE 481 Additive Manufacturing Processes", "IE596 Independent Study", and "IE392 Undergraduate Research".  Multiple graduate and undergraduate students were recruited to work on this project and being trained, including students from under-represented groups and low-income families.  Among them, two female PhD students graduated with dissertations developed or partially developed from this project and another female PhD student will graduate in 2023 with a dissertation majorly developed from this project.  More than ten journal papers were developed from this research and have been published.  Furthermore, the project results were disseminated widely to research communities through conferences and seminars and the general public through lab tours and news coverages.
